Yes, the relationship between religion and society is complex and constantly evolving. The way that religious institutions adapt to changing cultural norms varies depending on the specific institution and the cultures or societies they exist within.

Many religious institutions, including the Catholic Church, have faced similar challenges as the Anglican Church, particularly with regards to LGBTQ+ rights and the role of women. The Catholic Church has been grappling with the question of women's ordination for decades, and while some progress has been made, the church has yet to fully embrace the idea.

Similarly, many Muslim-majority countries have been debating the role of Islam in modern society, with some arguing for a more progressive interpretation of Islam that embraces gender equality and LGBTQ+ rights.

Overall, religious institutions are grappling with a changing world and are realizing the need to adapt and evolve in order to remain relevant to the societies they serve. The extent to which they are able to do so while maintaining their core values and beliefs is an ongoing question that requires further conversation and exploration.
